@robin-miller-ow  This task looks like it is still open in Jira https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-657
@davoscollective you are quite right, I must have forgotten to go back to the ticket. I have now closed the issue.

@ashb @mistercrunch 

It took some time because I had to figure out how to properly test the warning-system in Python 2.7 https://docs.python.org/2/library/warnings.html:  One thing to be aware of is that if a warning has already been raised because of a once/default rule, then no matter what filters are set the warning will not be seen again unless the warnings registry related to the warning has been cleared.
I got the solution here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19428761/python-showing-once-warnings-again-resetting-all-warning-registries

Therefore I had to add some code to properly reset the warning system to do the test. It is in now and everything is green. If there are any more questions, please let me know. If now, let me know if we're good to merge.

Cheers, Fokko
Anyone fancy clicking merge?
Turns out there are a few py3 incompatibilities here. I'll update this PR as time allows.
@bolkedebruin I will push other PR with following tests for the python code added. Thanks!

I'm  wondering if the  reason for the 1G limit is very postgres specific, and very generous. You really should only be passing at most a small dictionary or map between tasks. It's probably fair in that it's more than adequate but a good safety protection.

Regarding the absence of test, and the concern about not wanting to include a 1G file, you could generate a couple of fake files, one just under the limit size and one just over. A very small amount of code in the repo can be used to generate the files, then do the tests, then discard the files. 

I agree that failing would be preferable to silently inserting substitute data. Presumably xcoms are dependencies between tasks and downstream tasks are relying on it to continue the workflow. A fail on hard limit is easier to comprehend than a downstream tasks failing to unpickle expected xcom, principle of least surprise.

To add another data point, personally I would rather see an exception thrown in this case.  Although I don't typically use XCom for values that large — I'd typically write to disk or S3 and XCom just the file path for instance.  Is there a common use case for writing very large values to XCom?

I will say it is indeed generous but also very arbitrary. 

I agree that failure should be explicit. We had a case where our `variables` page was broken due to encrypted values getting silently truncated by MySQL which sucked to debug (we started by deleting the offending entries, and eventually realized they all had max length).
IDK, in Java, log4j and slf4j are both pretty popular solutions, and both use logger. But I am not really opposed either way; this just doesn't feel necessary to me.
One thing is I feel like the name logger is (slightly) more descriptive
Sorry I lost track of this. Thank you for including the screenshots.

This PR is way more useful than just adding DynamoDB. It adds boto's general "resource" API to the aws_hook, where previously it only had boto's "client". This will provide a good base for extending the AWS operators / sensors / hooks for other AWS services. I can see that there has been a significant addition of tasks for interacting with Google's cloud, but the AWS side now needs to catch up and this could contribute to that aim.
This bug was introduced by [AIRFLOW-1564](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1564). However, as the issue for this itself has been registered, we will switch the link to that.

I think supporting MySQL and PostGres (and compatibles like MariaDB and Aurora) is a reasonable scope. As long as the arbitrary limit covers worst case with those databases then it's reasonable, and given that reasoning, a limit determined that way would no longer be arbitrary. I've just checked my MetaDB (MySQL using InnoDB) and the `xcom` table has a `value` column of type `Blob`. Blobs can be max 65535 bytes (mediumblob and longblob are allowed to be larger, but the type used is Blob), which is 64K https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/blob.html. 

I'm checking the Postgres docs and there is a section listed regarding BLOB that directs to large object support, which apparently allows up to 4TB, but uses some off table-tricks & metadata pointers. The other method listed is `bytea` or `text` which has a 1G limit per entry, so I assume that it where this PR comes from. The technique uses `TOAST` which involves storing data across multiple fixed 8k page rows.  https://wiki.postgresql.org/wiki/BinaryFilesInDB 

There is also a section at the bottom "when is it a bad idea to store binary files in the database" which says "Very large files (100meg+), where performance is critical to the application. The database layer adds a lot of overhead and complexity that may not be required."  
100 may also be fairly arbitrary, but given the point of xcom is to be written and then read shortly after then minimizing this limit makes sense. 

_"~~640K~~ 64K ought to be enough for anybody"_

The code change is the same as in the #2441, except this adds the tests for the functionality.

@larrywongl The link for the job is already in the airflow logs. I haven't put the full jenkins log as sometime they get pretty big (some of our jobs have multiple Gb of logs ^^). But I think having the link for the jenkins job is usually enough for navigability.

@slpsys yes, this PR fixes the issue since every change of page now re-renders the page (from the server) and the javascript that would add the toggles to the switches.
Adding a comment on that ticket related to this PR. Thanks!
@edgarRd ok, awesome! Thanks for the clarification. I skimmed the code, but wasn't positive if the re-rendering would occur on each new page render/view.
@aoen do you mind reviewing this when you get a chance? or know who should ask?

For the most part, my current stance on the PRs for a lot of sensors and hooks) is that if one of the committers doesn't depend on the hook/sensor, then there isn't really much official support for them. Currently, a lot of them don't even have tests. I made a JIRA a while back to create a more formal plugin system for Airflow, but for now nothing is stoping users from creating their own github repos for their custom contrib stuff, and just adding their custom hooks/operators to PYTHONPATH so that DAGs can access them (Airbnb does this for some operators internally).

Another option is to become a committer to maintain the hooks you have a vested interest in!

LGTM

@chie8842 Please squash your commits

@chie8842 Please review the commit guidelines:

My commits all reference JIRA issues in their subject lines, and I have squashed multiple commits if they address the same issue. In addition, my commits follow the guidelines from "How to write a good git commit message":
- Subject is separated from body by a blank line
- Subject is limited to 50 characters
- Subject does not end with a period
- Subject uses the imperative mood ("add", not "adding")
- Body wraps at 72 characters
- Body explains "what" and "why", not "how"

Your commit should start with `[AIRFLOW-1331]` and it should be a single commit (not two as now).

Perfect, @bolkedebruin can you merge?

@aoen thanks for that response :). Greatly appreciated, I/we may be interested in becoming a maintainer of hooks have an interest in like you said. Is there a place to get more information about that?

@larrywongl : I'm doing my best to get this merged, but it's my first contribution to this project (and also the first time I'm writing python) so I prefer to has as much eyes on it as possible to ensure a good quality  :). 
For the url, I've been using the python-jenkins library to trigger the job on jenkins, and the URL for the job is exposed through the build_info object : 
`build_info = jenkins_server.get_build_info(job_name=self.job_name, build_number=build_number)`
`build_info['url]' # <- contains the URL of the job, add /log at the end for a direct link to the logs`

And if you need the plugin before it get merged, you can still pick the commit (or only the file it contains and inject that in your airflow installation, that what we're doing at CK until a new version of airflow contains the operator :) )

@skudriashev @bolkedebruin @jgao54 Do you have any other comment/review on things I can still enhance before we can merge this PR ? I would like to be able to make it for the 1.8.3 (if possible :D ).
And thanks again for all your comment and your help for this PR ;)
@dalupus, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @bolkedebruin, @mistercrunch and @AllisonWang to be potential reviewers.

There are no hard and fast requirements but I don't think we've had a case of someone putting in the effort and doing a decent job being rejected. In general you want to: have one big commit, maybe 7-8 smaller ones (at least a couple of which touch the core, not hooks/operators), help review PRs, be involved in the mailing list discussions. No hard and fast rules, and the committers need to vote, but I think those are some good rough ones.

Awesome that's really good to know. Thanks @aoen  :)

I realise it's done and the debate over, but here's two other reasons in support of why this is a good change, rather than just being a convention of other languages.
1. Shorter, helps with keeping to less than 80 chars
2. Function calls read in the imperative as verb.noun , e.g. "log.info" is more descriptive than "logger.info"
@criccomini Any chance we can get this in 1.9? I can help test it if needed, but looks like a pretty straightforward PR.
Thanks for the contribution. Please adhere to the commit guidelines and provide a JIRA en proper commit subject/Message.

Thanks for the reviews! I've only put a 1GB limit as a safety precaution. On the Airflow fork we work with we use a much smaller limit (1MB), but I did not want to add an arbitrary behaviour to the original project. 

I understand why raising an exception may be a better option, but in the other hand if I'm not mistaken an _xcom_push_ is automatically triggered if your task has a return value. Which means that when dealing with big return values you must change your task behaviour for your DAG to terminate (for example by pushing the value to disk and returning the filepath as suggested @tedmiston). If this is the best way to do it, maybe we could add a section to the xcom part of the documentation.

Another solution I see would be to modify the _run_raw_task function in airflow/models.py to make it possible to disable automatic _xcom_push_. 

What do you guys think ?
@bolkedebruin is it the way you want now?
